Jim writes : Dictionaries define one-way in relation to traffic as allowing travel in one direction only. This does not cover the common NZ one-way bridge, across which a vehicle may travel in either direction unless there is opposing traffic. That is, it can be crossed only one way at a time. Although the distinction is a fine one, it seems real. Possibly the term one-way bridge is itself distinctive NZE. The latest NZ Road Code uses the term one-lane bridge.

I have heard (before 1939?) the expression be on one's onkus = `be on the bones of one's arse, broke'; or `be one's last legs' I had always thought of the word as `honkers', probably arbitrarily seeing in it `hunkers' or `haunches', euphemism for `arse', as the concrete expressions were `get up off your onkus', `get up off you behind (and start working etc',) ... `sitting around on your onkus'. An Oonst Oonst Oonst That Could Not Be Heard: The Secret History of Electronic Music, techno was actually invented in 1962 by Herman Poltswalski, a shoe salesman and dedicated electronics audio hobbyist from Eau Claire, Wisconsin. He called the beat-driven music that he coaxed from his home-made synthesizers and drum machines "indestructible polka" despite the fact that it generally followed a 4/4 beat and exceeded the speed of the fastest polkas by about 30 bpm. a betting place in the open, near a racecourse
[sp. use] harvesting train consisting of traction engine, flat-top trolley, cutter, galley and the travelling hut.

Notes: [Is this form a specific gang name.]

Definition: a horse with a tendency to buck or pigjump.
a difficult horse to break in or catch.
an animal that does not conform.
an electrified wire attached to a conventional fence; an electrified wire placed away from the main fence but attached to it
a wire construction beside or on top of a fence to prevent bulls, horses and other stock from reaching over or trampling the fence.
a movement of a sheepdog when directed to move around a mob of sheep.
a part of a dog-trial event.
esp. GO OUTSIDE, to go outside the Sounds into the Strait; beyond the Entrance
Notes: ca1941 on the Tamahine `It's pretty rough outside. Go easy on the fizz.

Definition: the longest and most onerous mustering area, circumnavigating a block boundary.
a musterer with a long and onerous beat around the boundary of a block.
a stock yard away from the main station or woolshed [often at an outstation.]
as abbrev. of MAORI etc. OVEN =HANGI, =UMU

Notes: 1981 Feb Avondale College (Auckland) Slang Words in Use (Goldie Brown Collection) bun in the oven: expecting a baby
also Chathams and Stewart Isds usage
As in "he overed with the winter party" - heard in a radio documentary on Antarctica in Spectrum;

Definition: across the shearing board [used with reference to the shearing of sheep, or the use of the shearing board to crutch or to examine sheep].

Notes: cf. 1984 14 F E131 Wgton Girls C. 7 OFF THE FENCE [something not good]

Definition: to Christchurch over the Port Hills from Lyttelton, and vice versa.
to dip sheep using a plunge or pot dip.
indicating a position nearby or over the road
droving sheep for too long at one time.
[of a sheepdog] too strongly eyed [so that many sheep become transfixed by his/her gaze.]
[of farm stock] carrying too much fat.
[used elsewhere, but recorded first in NZ] the increase in bulk when butterfat is made into butter.
to surface sow seed over existing ground cover.
the surface sowing of seed over exisiting ground cover.
[droving] to push stock too hard and fast.
[of animals for slaughter] overweight or overprimed.
an overweight animal, usually for slaughter.
to allow stock to remain too long on a crop or pasture or to place too many stock in one area.
fleece wool which is more than 12 months wool growth; If very long = DOUBLE FLEECE
of a building, a room built above a garage
a shelter rock in a mountain area under which musterers, hunters and stock can camp.

Notes: Internet search Feb 2006: 1 citation found in Austral.

Definition: a long shaft in a shearing shed from which shearing machines are suspended and driven.
[dog trial heading dog] to run too far around the back of a mob of sheep.
[dog trial huntaway dog] placing too much pressure on sheep too soon in a run.
spec meaning distinguishing land or cross-country travel from sea transport and travel in early NZ
[sp. use] to drive stock long distances over land.
as distinct from sea-mail (?explained in Nelson Examiner ? in McLean Papers: frequent in early journals etc, e.g. McLean Papers) abbrev. o.m.
one who drives stock a long distance
a drover or stockowner who drives sheep long distances over land rather than by road.
the daytime passenger train between Wellington and Auckland
[of huntaway sheepdogs] noisy to the extreme.
[sheepdogs] to make too long an arc when heading sheep.
[non-rural] practice of the position of workplace overseer
Farm or station; practice of the position of overseer
the excess removing of britch and peripheral wool from a fleece.
the sowing of seed on land that already carries some growth, eg scrub, in order to protect seed.
hill country native tussock land surface sown with exotic grasses.
a visitor who has not left New Zealand by the date required by a visa etc.
Notes: 1981 Feb Avondale College (Auckland) Slang Words in Use (Goldie Brown Collection) overstayer. Bruce Rampton (Rampton Crighton & Co, Box 17-364, Wellington) wrote on 21/9/1999 that the word was still in use and sent a copy of part of a statement of claim filed in the court "...The family was informed by the New Zealand Immigration Service on or about 30 July 1997 that they must leave New Zealand immediately on the grounds that they were illegal overstayers in New Zealand."

Definition: to run more stock than land can supportalso OVERSTOCKING
[sp. use] a fat/prime lamb weighing more than 36 lbs.
someone who spends the winter in the Antarctic

morepork or whekauOwl, n. an English bird name. In New Zealand, the species are - Laughing Jackass, or L. Owl, Sceloglaux albifacies, Kaup (Maori name, Whekau, q.v.), and the Morepork, formerly Athene novae-zelandiae, Gray, now Spiloglaux novae-zelandiae, Kaup. (See Morepork).
an old name for the kakapo.

Notes: Jim Cameron writes: The DNZE definition is not precisely accurate, in that the occupier may not be able to hold the freehold; the basic title may be leasehold, or the apartment may be occupied under a company lease system. These would nonetheless normally be referred to as OYO properties.
see also Morris entry 1898 See AUCKLAND ROCK, BLUFF, DREDGE, FOVEAUX STRAIT, PACIFIC, STEWART, MUD

CC Ransom notes: Is this the DRILL or OYSTER DRILL (Urosalpinx sp) that bores holes in oysters: a marine snail? There are a number of snails that attack molluscs but U. cinerea is said to be the oyster-specialist.

Definition: Haemotopus spp. =SEA PIE, also called redbill, torea black or black and white wader of seashores and estuaries, having a long orange bill with which it picks out small molluscs and worms. spg also oyster(-)catcher
in fig. and transf. use - (usually pl.) (freezing works) sweetbreads
(usually pl.) (children's) opaque brown and grey marbles
Notes: also smokies ca early 1950's Naenae Wellington
